properties.affiliatio: USGS Geology, Geophysics, and Geochemistry Science Center;USGS Geology, Energy & Minerals Science Center
properties.pdescrip: Hyperspectral mapping of the Southwestern US
properties.pkeyword: AVIRIS; lithium; geologic maps; interagency programs; alteration; study areas; critical minerals; hyperspectral imaging; natural resource exploration
properties.abstract: Visible to shortwave infrared (VSWIR) imaging spectrometer (also known as hyperspectral) data will be acquired over ~500,000 km2 of the Southwestern United States under an interagency agreement (IAA) with NASA, using their AVIRIS (Airborne Visible InfraRed Imaging Spectrometer) sensors. VSWIR data, derived mineral maps and other interpretive products will provide actionable information on the location and formation of critical minerals related to both hydrothermal alteration and rock weathering processes. This will also include potential lithium deposits contained in numerous evaporite deposits in closed basins exposed throughout the Basin and Range. Additional data will be acquired using one of several thermal infrared (TIR) sensors (e.g., NASAâ€™s HyTES and/or MASTER instruments) which will support discrimination, identification, and mapping of primary rock-forming minerals. The latter data will also aid in geologic mapping and mine waste sampling efforts being undertaken by those states. The primary (or highest priority) collection area was designed in order to complete existing large area data collections across the states of California and Nevada, including adjacent portions of Southern Arizona. These areas contain numerous mines and other geologic and land-use features which will benefit from studies utilizing hyperspectral data covering those areas. For example, natural hazard related studies such as volcanoes, landslides, wildfires, floods, earthquakes, snowpack monitoring, dust emissions and wildfire-induced debris flow mapping will also benefit from the acquisition of this data.

keywords.scope: Alkali metal element with symbol Li and atomic number 3 <http://periodic.lanl.gov/3.shtml>

Maps depicting geological characteristics of the earth's surface, including lithology, geologic structure, age, and the results of crustal processes. Used where the product includes a depiction of the map as a whole, not for data sets that could be used to create a map.
Ongoing organizational activities in which USGS works directly with other government agencies
Local changes in the mineralogy of a rock body due to low-grade metamorphism, weathering, or both.  May indicate underlying mineral deposits.
Geospatial data describing the areas from which samples were taken or observations were made, typically polygonal.  May be approximate, as in bounding coordinates, or precise.

A non-fuel mineral or mineral material essential to the economic and national security of the US, the supply chain of which is vulnerable to disruption, and that serves an essential function in the manufacturing of a product, the absence of which would have significant consequences for our economy or our national security.
Multispectral imaging technique that records many bands of imagery at very narrow bandwidths.
Techniques for locating deposits or stocks of useful minerals, water, and other resources using reconnaissance or instrumental methods.
Areas where masses of naturally occurring mineral material are found, e.g. metal ores or nonmetallic minerals. [Adapted from Glossary of Geology, 4th ed.]
A nonclastic sedimentary rock composed primarily of minerals produced from a saline solution as a result of extensive or total evaporation of the solvent.
